areaSection: Finestrat is a municipality on the Costa Blanca in Alicante province, positioned between the popular destinations of Benidorm and Altea. Finestrat enjoys a Mediterranean climate with over 300 days of sunshine annually, mild winters averaging 12-15°C, and warm summers around 28-30°C. The location offers the perfect balance: close enough to major infrastructure and amenities, yet removed from the overcrowding of neighboring resort towns. The town has undergone significant development with quality residential projects, attracting both permanent residents and investors. Its proximity to Alicante airport (45 minutes) and the N-332 coastal road makes it highly accessible. The combination of natural beauty, modern infrastructure, and relatively affordable pricing compared to neighboring areas has established Finestrat as an increasingly attractive investment destination for international property buyers.

The beaches at Playa Paraiso and Playa Centro, both Blue Flag rated, are just 15-20 minutes away by car, perfect for weekend relaxation or rental guest entertainment. Multiple championship golf courses nearby cater to the significant golfing community. The expat infrastructure means finding English-speaking services, international restaurants, and familiar amenities is straightforward. Public transport connects the town to nearby areas, though having a car provides the flexibility most residents prefer. The combination of modern living standards, healthcare quality, and established international networks makes Finestrat an increasingly popular choice for both lifestyle and investment-focused buyers seeking practical, reliable locations.

faqs.question: La Costa Blanca est-elle un bon endroit pour acheter un bien immobilier ?

faqs.question: Les étrangers peuvent-ils acheter un bien immobilier en Espagne ?
faqs.answer: Yes, foreigners can purchase property in Spain without restrictions. Most foreign buyers require a Spanish tax identification number (NIE) and must complete standard conveyancing procedures. British, European, and international buyers have equal property purchase rights. Many Spanish banks offer mortgages to non-resident foreign buyers. Legal representation is advisable to navigate tax and compliance requirements.

faqs.question: Quels sont les frais d'achat d'un bien immobilier en Espagne ?
faqs.answer: Total acquisition costs typically range 8-12% of purchase price. This includes: transfer tax (6-8%, varies by region), notary fees (€400-€800), property registry fees (€300-€500), and legal representation (€800-€1,500). For this property, expect approximately €25,600-€38,400 in additional acquisition costs. Financing costs add 0.3-0.8% if obtaining mortgages.

faqs.question: Puis-je obtenir un prêt hypothécaire en Espagne en tant qu'étranger ?
faqs.answer: Yes, foreign buyers can obtain Spanish mortgages. Typical loan-to-value ratios range 60-70%, requiring 30-40% deposit. Interest rates for foreign buyers are competitive (currently 3.5-4.5% for 20-year terms). Major Spanish banks including Santander, BBVA, and CaixaBank offer non-resident mortgages. Documentation requirements include proof of income, credit history, and identification. Spanish mortgage processes typically complete in 4-6 weeks.

faqs.question: Quel est le coût de la vie sur la Costa Blanca ?
faqs.answer: Costa Blanca cost of living is 25-35% lower than UK equivalents. Monthly expenses for one person average €1,000-€1,500 (rent excluded), including groceries (€250-€350), utilities (€100-€150), and dining (€200-€300). Healthcare is affordable through public system or private insurance (€100-€200/month). Property taxes (IBI) average 0.4-0.6% of cadastral value annually, approximately €300-€500 for this property. Rental income can substantially offset personal living costs.

faqs.question: Ai-je besoin d'un visa pour acheter un bien en Espagne ?
faqs.answer: No visa is required specifically for property purchase. Non-EU citizens can purchase property as tourists or through investment visa programs. EU/UK citizens benefit from visa-free travel agreements. However, non-EU residents may eventually require residence permits if planning extended stays (typically 90+ days). Property ownership facilitates residency applications but doesn't automatically grant permission. Consult Spanish consulate for your nationality's specific requirements.

faqs.question: How much rental income can I generate from this apartment?
faqs.answer: This 2-bedroom apartment typically generates €750-€850 per week in holiday lettings, or approximately €39,000-€44,000 annual gross revenue at full occupancy. At realistic 60% occupancy rates (conservative for coastal locations), annual rental income reaches €23,400-€26,400. Property management costs (15-25% of rental income) and maintenance expenses (5-10%) reduce net returns to approximately €16,000-€20,000 annually, representing 5-6.2% net yield on the €319,900 purchase price.

faqs.question: Quel temps fait-il sur la Costa Blanca ?
faqs.answer: Costa Blanca enjoys Mediterranean climate with over 300 days of sunshine annually. Winters are mild (12-15°C average) with minimal rainfall. Summers reach comfortable 28-30°C, moderated by sea breezes. Spring and autumn temperatures average 18-24°C - ideal for outdoor activities and touring guests. Humidity levels remain moderate compared to tropical destinations. This consistent weather supports year-round rental demand and makes the area attractive to international residents and holiday visitors.
